Effect of potassium addition on a long term performance of Co–ZnO–Al2O3 catalysts in the low-temperature steam reforming of ethanol: Co-precipitation vs citrate method of catalysts synthesis Bogna Banach ⁎ Andrzej Machocki Faculty of Chemistry, University of Maria Curie-Sklodowska, 3 Maria Curie-Sklodowska Square, 20-031 Lublin, Poland Faculty of Chemistry University of Maria Curie-Sklodowska 3 Maria Curie-Sklodowska Square Lublin 20-031 Poland ⁎ Corresponding author at: University of Maria Curie-Sklodowska, Faculty of Chemistry, Department of Chemical Technology 3, Maria Curie-Sklodowska Square, 20-031 Lublin, Poland. Fax: +48 815375565. Graphical abstract The promotion effect of potassium on Co–ZnO–Al2O3 catalysts in the steam reforming of ethanol has been studied with samples prepared by co-precipitation and citrate methods. Experimental results of catalytic activity, selectivity and coke deposition phenomena are reported. Potassium addition (1 and 2wt.%) had a significant influence on catalytic efficiency at various ethanol+water vapours streams (H2O:EtOH=21:1, 15:1, 12:1 molar ratios). It acts as a promoter improving catalyst stability, activity as well as marginalizing coke deposition on the catalyst surface. Catalysts prepared by the co-precipitation method, with smaller cobalt active phase crystallites and with potassium deposited on the catalyst surface are more stable in the steam reforming of ethanol than those with large crystallites prepared by citrate method, into which potassium was introduced together with all others components. The efficiency of the potassium promotion is higher when it is deposited on the catalyst surface with smaller cobalt active phase crystallites. The water excess equivalent to the H2O:EtOH molar ratio higher than 15:1 has been necessary for the stable SRE. Even potassium-promoted K–Co–ZnO–Al2O3 catalyst needs the ethanol–water feed with a large excess of water. Keywords Hydrogen Ethanol Steam reforming Carbonaceous deposit Cobalt catalysts Raman spectroscopy 1 Introduction Providing an clean and secure renewable energy source is one of the key challenges facing mankind nowadays. Hydrogen is potentially an ideal energy carrier, as it is non-polluting, oxidized yields only water. Hydrogen production from fossil fuels will continue to play an important role in at least next decade, while many challenges will have to be overcame for hydrogen to be used broadly in a sustainable future energy systems [1]. To achieve the greatest benefit for the environment, a low cost, low polluting and low-carbon intensive process for hydrogen production from renewable sources need to be developed. The light ethyl alcohol seems to be a highly realistic candidate as a chemical carrier of hydrogen [2]. Currently bioethanol is produced by fermentation of sugar cane, corn grains and other starch-rich materials. Technology focusing on the production of ethanol from lignocellulosic biomass open up the possibility for utilization of low-cost biomass (agricultural wastes and forests residues, such as straw, grasses, corn stover, wood). In this way, food could be produced along with bioethanol from agricultural sources [1–3]. Moreover, systems which allow to produce hydrogen from bioethanol have the advantage of being carbon dioxide neutral. Ethanol is interesting also due to: (i) low toxicity, (ii) moderate production costs, (iii) high hydrogen content, H:C=3, (iv) availability and (v) easy handling. Though there are several possibilities of gaining hydrogen from bioethanol the one which was used in this work is the steam reforming of ethanol (SRE). A catalyst for the SRE, in order to gain high hydrogen selectivity, must be able to: (i) dehydrogenate ethanol, (ii) break CC bonds, (iii) reform C1 products to generate hydrogen [4]. According to the stoichiometry of the SRE reaction (1) C2H5OH+3H2O→6H2 +3CO2 maximum yield of hydrogen is 6mol with respect to 1mol of ethanol reacted, what is a very good point of this process. However, the final hydrogen yield/efficiency will depend on the intensity and the state of the equilibrium of the water gas shift reaction (WGS) as well as successful inhibition of non-selective transformations of ethanol to acetaldehyde, ethylene, methane, acetone and other by-products which are formed in side reactions [5]. According to current studies cobalt as well as noble metals seems to be a very promising active phase in the steam reforming of ethanol [6–13,15–25]. There are made an extensive studies in developing a catalyst for the SRE which could operate at relatively low temperature without by-products formation, which is also resistant to carbon deposition [6–10]. Several research groups investigated ethanol reforming on catalysts containing cobalt supported on ZnO or ZnO–Al2O3 [9–13,15–17]. According to the research made by Llorca et al. [11] and Chiou et al. [17] small particle size of cobalt supported on zinc oxide results in good catalyst performance during the SRE process and allows to decrease or even eliminate carbon monoxide formation [11]. In another studies Llorca et al. [15] and Casanovas et al. [16] confirmed the positive effect, in terms of hydrogen yield and the SRE process stability, of potassium and sodium addition on catalytic properties of the Co/ZnO. The good catalytic performance were also showed by catalysts containing cobalt, zinc oxide and aluminium oxide [12,13]. According to X. Wang et al. [14] addition of Al2O3 has two effects (i) it increases the surface area and improves cobalt particles dispersion, (ii) it enhances the interactions between cobalt and a catalyst support. The behaviour of cobalt catalysts depends also on the SRE reaction conditions. Chiou et al. [17] studied the steam reforming of ethanol over Co/ZnO catalysts with 5–20wt.% cobalt loading. The process was carried out between 200 and 500°C, at the atmospheric pressure, using a H2O:EtOH=13:1 molar ratio+Ar stream. Catalysts were also reduced in H2 at 200°C for 3h. For 20wt.% Co/ZnO catalyst the conversion of ethanol increased with temperature and at about 400°C, reached the value of 100% simultaneously with a high selectivity to hydrogen and carbon dioxide. Meanwhile, the long stability test at 375°C showed rapid decrease of ethanol conversion after 8h. Also Llorca et al. [11] investigated the SRE (H2O:EtOH=13:1 molar ratio+Ar) over catalysts composed of cobalt active phase (10wt.%) supported over zinc oxide. The reduced Co/ZnO (impregnated with cobalt nitrate and Co/ZnO catalysts impregnated with Co(CO)4 solution) showed the best performance. Ethanol was converted completely at the temperature range of 350–450°C. The main products obtained after 24–26h of the reaction were hydrogen and carbon dioxide. Furthermore, a long-term stability test showed that Co/ZnO catalyst obtained from cobalt carbonyl is very resistant to carbon monoxide formation at the temperature as low as 350°C. Researches mentioned above suggested that performance of the Co/ZnO catalysts depend on the cobalt precursor, cobalt particle size and the presence of CoO phase [11,17]. Llorca et al. [11], assumed that consistent decrease of H2O+EtOH mixture dilution as well as an increasing of the space velocity lead to non-selective transformation during which CO and CH3CHO appear. Martí et al. [21] performed the SRE test over bulk cobalt catalysts (H2O:EtOH=13:1–6:1 molar ratios+He, T =375°C). The catalytic behaviour of catalyst was improving while the ratio increased, nevertheless the deactivation process appeared. The conversion of ethanol was decreasing with time, simultaneously with an increase of carbon monoxide and aldehyde formation. Marti et al. [21] and Pereira et al. [22] presented the beneficial effect of potassium (4.5wt.%) and sodium (0.5wt.%) addition to the bulk cobalt catalysts. Both catalysts exhibited a very good performance in the SRE (H2O:EtOH=6:1 molar ratio+He, T =375–400°C). The products distribution exhibited mainly hydrogen, carbon dioxide and some amounts of methane. Carbon monoxide was present only over Co(Na) catalyst at 400°C [22]. For that catalyst also traced amounts of ethylene (≤0.2%) were detected. Espinal et al. [24] came to conclusions that potassium acts as a promoter enabling to increase the ethanol conversion at lower temperature what had a positive effect in a long term stability test under SRE conditions (H2O:EtOH=4:1 molar ratio+N2, T =550°C); for the Co/Mg/Al catalyst with potassium addition (1wt.%) the only products were H2, CO2, CO and CH4. With increasing amount of potassium (from 0.5 to 2wt.%) the selectivity at the low-temperature steam reforming (≤450°C) increased towards H2 and CO2 while decrease to CH3CHO and (CH3)2CO. Authors concluded that potassium reduced the number and strength of acid sides in the catalysts support. Research accomplished by Llorca et al. [15] and Casanovas et al. [16] demonstrated a significant enhancement of a catalytic performance towards ethanol steam reforming when alkali dopants were used. The Co(Na)/ZnO catalyst (10wt.% Co, 1wt.% Na) was more active and more selective towards reforming products, H2 and CO2, in respect to the bare Co/ZnO (H2O:EtOH=6:1 molar ratio+He, T =300-500°C, pre-treatment with N2 +H2) [16]. A long-term experiment designed by Llorca et al. [15] (SRE conditions: H2O:EtOH=13:1 molar ratio+Ar) showed reversed dependency between sodium content and catalysts deactivation. The 0.98NaCoZn catalyst deactivation was equal to only 2%, whereas, for the 0.06NaCoZn was as high as 21%. During 240h test at 400°C under steam+ethanol stream over the 0.98NaCoZn catalyst the ethanol conversion were complete and only CH4 (∼1.6%) and CO (<0.6%) was obtained as by-products [15]. Ogo et al. [25] investigated promoting effect of potassium on Co/Al2O3 catalyst for SRE process using operando DRIFTS technique. Authors concluded that formation of Co0-CoO core shell structure over Co/K/Al2O3 catalyst was effective for improvement of catalyst activity and for suppression of coke formation. The drawback of cobalt catalysts for the SRE is (i) low thermal resistance and (ii) possibility of carbon deposits formation. Steam reforming reactions are strongly endothermic and need a continuous heat supplies. Therefore, it is recommended to develop a catalyst to perform the low-temperature SRE process which in turn will lead to build a robust and safe reformer. The second issue, formation of filamentous or amorphous carbon on cobalt catalysts, is also widely studied [10,23,25–29]. A crucial aspect is the prevention of coke formation, what can be achieved in two ways: by prevention of carbon formation reactions or by rapid carbon conversion to gaseous products. From several strategies, limitation of coke formation can be accomplished with a high steam/ethanol ratio and/or catalyst modification. Increasing steam to ethanol molar ratio in the feed results in easier carbon gasification. For the 10wt.% Co/CeO2 catalyst (the SRE at 500°C) a decrease in amount of carbonaceous species was observed when water/ethanol ratio was increased from 3 to 10 [29]. The second strategy, catalyst modification, is related to its influence on catalyst stability during the SRE process. Several studies deal with the topic of modifying of acid/base properties of the support through the addition of alkali metals, such as lithium, sodium, potassium, magnesium, lanthanum and cerium [10,15,16,24,30–33]. The primary purpose of adding promoters with alkali properties to catalysts was limitation of carbon deposition during the SRE process [15,33]. Moreover, potassium acts as the promoter favouring the ethanol conversion at a low temperature of the SRE [34]. The addition of potassium or sodium leads to the improvement of catalysts activity and selectivity to hydrogen and carbon dioxide [10,15,16,24,30–33]. Investigations of coke deposition on catalysts are very important due to the possibility decrease of catalysts stability which may be attributed in a large extend to this phenomenon. Barroso et al. [12] inferred that in the case of the CoZnAl (25wt.% of Co) catalyst carbon deposition (between 21 and 41% of coke) was non-homogeneous what did not affect the catalyst performance under SRE (H2O:EtOH=4:1 molar ratio, ∼4h). According to Llorca et al. [15] sodium addition (∼1wt.%) to a 10wt.% Co/ZnO catalyst improved its performance (H2 yield, stability) in the SRE (H2O:EtOH=4:1 molar ratio+Ar) due to inhibition of abundant carbonaceous deposit. Espinal et al. [24] found that dopping of the Co/Mg/Al catalysts with potassium reduced the number and the strength of acid sites, what hindered coke formation during stream reforming of ethanol. Río et al. [23] investigated the Co3O4 catalyst supported on SSWM (stainless steel wire mesh) containing ∼46% of cobalt oxide in the SRE (2vol% EtOH and 12vol% of H2O+N2, WHSV=1.64h−1, 400°C). Cobalt oxide particles without potassium were massively reduced to metallic cobalt and large amounts of coke were formed. They came to the conclusion that the presence of potassium on the catalyst surface prevents its over-reduction to metallic cobalt as well as limits the carbonaceous species deposition on the surface of Co0 particles. This statement was also confirmed by Ogo et al. [25] in the case of Co/K/Al2O3 catalyst. The aim for this study is to find general issues that enable us to improve the cobalt catalyst performance in the low temperature SRE process. Our reasoning is to combine a good catalytic activity of cobalt in the steam reforming and basic properties of a support with potassium ability to reduce carbon deposition formation. Previous studies showed that the optimum content of the cobalt active phase is approximately equal to 24wt.%, and that the temperature of 420°C for the steam reforming of ethanol performed over Co–ZnO–Al2O3 catalyst is the most advantageous for hydrogen-rich gas production [18]. The Co–ZnO–Al2O3 catalyst was doped with potassium at weight percentages of 1 and 2. Two series of catalysts were prepared, the first series using the co-precipitation method and the second-by using the citrate method. Also, the introduction of potassium for each series was different. For co-precipitated catalysts, potassium was incorporated in the second step during impregnation with a K2CO3 aqueous solution. In the case of catalysts prepared by citrate method all ingredients were added in one step. The influence of potassium loading on catalysts activity, selectivity and stability as well as coke formation phenomena was evaluated in the low temperature steam reforming of ethanol (420°C, H2O:EtOH molar ratio equal to 21:1 simulating a fermentation broth). Selected catalysts performance under the feed of H2O:EtOH equal to 15:1 and 12:1 molar ratios was also analysed in the terms of potassium ability to limit coke formation and to improve catalysts activity, selectivity and their stability under various SRE conditions. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalysts preparation ZnO-supported cobalt catalysts were prepared by the co-precipitation and citrate methods from Zn(CH3COO)2, Al(NO3)3 and Co(CH3COO)2 aqueous solutions. The precipitation was accomplished at 40°C by addition of (NH4)2CO3 solution to the zinc-, cobalt- and aluminium-containing solution, drop by drop, under continuous stirring of suspension. After ageing of precipitates at 55°C for 3h, the suspension was filtered. The filtrate was washed with an absolute ethanol, in order to remove water from the precipitate (precursor of the catalyst). The obtained solid was dried over night at 110°C and then calcined at 400°C. To the prepared catalyst, potassium (1 and 2wt.%) was added in the second step by incipient wetness impregnation using aqueous solutions of KNO3. After impregnation, K-doped catalysts were dried over night at 110°C and then calcined at 400°C. The catalysts were labelled as 0K-PR, 1K-PR and 2K-PR, where the number means the weight percent of potassium. For catalysts prepared with the citrate method, citric acid was added to aqueous solutions that contained all the required salts Zn(CH3COO)2, Al(NO3)3, Co(CH3COO)2 and KNO3 (except of the sample without potassium addition). The molar ratio of all metal ions (Zn2+, Al3+ and Co2+) to citric acid was 1/1. The resultant solutions were evaporated on a water bath. The obtained solids were dried at 110°C and then calcined at 400°C. The catalysts were labelled as 0K-CA, 1K-CA and 2K-CA, depending on the potassium promoter amount. The average amount of alumina in each of catalysts was ∼4wt.%. All catalyst samples were pressed, crushed and sieved, and the 0.15–0.3mm fraction was used for catalytic measurements. 2.2 Characterization X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) was used to determine the bulk content of cobalt in catalysts. Spectra were obtained with a XRF spectrometer (Canberra 1510) equipped with a liquid nitrogen-cooled Si(Li) detector. The AXIL software package for spectra deconvolution and for the calculation of cobalt content was used. The BET surface area of catalysts was measured by the low-temperature (−196°C) nitrogen adsorption in the ASAP 2405N v1.0 analyser (Micromeritics). X-ray powder diffraction patterns of catalysts were recorded with the Empyrean (PANalytical) diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation at 40kV/20mA at λ =1.54187Å and a PIXcel3D detector. The data were collected at 25°C in the range of 15–100° with intervals of 0.026°. The International Centre for Diffraction Data (ICDD) PDF-4+ database was used for phase identification. The average size of Co3O4 crystallites was estimated from X-ray diffraction line broadening of the appropriate peaks corresponding to Co3O4 (2θ =59.35°). Temperature-programmed reduction of catalysts was carried out in an AMI-1 analyser (Altamira Instruments Inc.) using 0.05g of the catalyst. A 6% H2–Ar mixture was used at a flow rate of 30cm3 min−1 with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 (25–800°C). The water vapour formed during reduction was removed in a cold trap (immersed in a liquid nitrogen–methanol slush) placed downstream of the thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The Raman spectra were recorded in the Raman microscope (inVia Reflex, Renishaw) with Raman dispersive system, using the 785nm semiconducting laser. In order to avoid sample overheating 0.5mW of laser power was used. The spectra of all samples were recorded at room temperature. Hydrogen chemisorption was measured in an Autosorb-1-C analyser (Quantachrome). Prior to the measurements, catalysts were reduced in situ with hydrogen at 400°C for 1h. Then, they were cooled down to 300°C under flowing H2, degassed at that temperature under vacuum of 5×10−7 Pa and, after cooling to 40°C, the hydrogen chemisorption was measured. The uptake of hydrogen was determined by extrapolating the straight-line portion of the total hydrogen chemisorption isotherm (up to the equilibrium pressure of 13.3kPa) to zero pressure. The surface area of the cobalt active phase was calculated assuming a chemisorption stoichiometry Co:H=1:1 and that the surface area occupied by one atom of hydrogen is 0.065nm2. The average size of cobalt crystallites was calculated from the equation d =(6×103)/(g Co × S Co), where g Co is the density of cobalt and S Co is the surface area of cobalt (m2/g Co). 2.3 Catalytic measurements The steam reforming of ethanol was carried out in a fixed-bed continuous-flow quartz reactor over catalysts reduced in situ with hydrogen at 400°C for 1h prior to the reaction studies. The catalysts (0.1g) were diluted (at the weight ratio 1:10) with grains of quartz in order to ensure constant temperature in the catalytic layer. In a preliminary experiment it was found that the conversion of ethanol over quartz starts, to a small extent, at higher temperatures (>700°C) than those at which the steam reforming of ethanol in the presence of catalysts was investigated. The aqueous solution of ethanol (H2O:EtOH molar ratio equal to 21:1, 15:1 and 12:1) was supplied by mass controller (Bronkhorst) to an evaporator (140°C) and the reactants vapours (at a flow rate of 100ml/min), without diluting with any inert gas, were fed to the reactor. The reaction temperature measured in the centre of the catalyst+quartz bed, was fixed at 420°C. The analysis of the reaction mixture and the reaction products (all in the gas phase) were carried out on-line by means of two gas chromatographs. One of them, Varian CP-3800 was equipped with two capillary columns, the first one contained a porous polymer Porapak Q (for all organics, carbon dioxide and water vapour) and the second of them — an activated molecular sieve 5Å (for methane and carbon monoxide analysis). Helium was used as a carrier gas and a TCD detector was employed. The hydrogen concentration was analysed by the second gas chromatograph, Chromatron GCHF 18.3, using a column packed with an activated charcoal, nitrogen as a carrier gas and a TCD detector. All calculations of conversions and selectivity of the SRE can be found in the previous work [18]. Studies of the catalyst coking under the steam reforming of ethanol conditions were performed by the gravimetric method using the TG121 microbalance system (Cahn), under dynamic conditions in a quartz reactor with a continuous flow of ethanol–water vapours. The sensitivity of the balance was 0.1μg. Those experiments simulated the activity measurement tests but the catalyst sample was placed on a small quartz plate. The samples (0.01g, 0.15–0.30mm) were reduced in-situ (with hydrogen at 400°C for 1h) prior to the reaction. After activation catalysts samples were flushed with nitrogen and heated up to the 420°C and nitrogen was replaced by reactant vapours at a flow rate of 100ml/min. The reaction was continued for one day in the ethanol and water vapour mixture with molar ratios of H2O:EtOH equal to 21:1, 15:1 and 12:1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Table 1 compiles the synthesized catalysts along with their cobalt contents, specific surface area and cobalt surface area. The preparation method influenced the amount of cobalt in the catalysts. Taking into account that the same amounts of salts were used in both preparation method, co-precipitation allowed to prepare catalysts with higher cobalt content (28.1wt.%). The specific surface area values are higher for co-precipitated catalysts and potassium addition procedure leads to a slight decrease of its specific surface area. Table 1 contains also the mean size of cobalt species crystallites (in means of Co3O4 and Zn x Co3-x O4) in calcined catalysts as calculated from the Scherrer equation. Cobalt oxide particle size was in the range of 16–23nm. Incorporation of the promoter does not seem to have a significant effect on cobalt oxide and double oxide particles size. Because of the pyrophoricity of reduced catalysts, even if they were carefully passivated, it was impossible to evaluate the mean size of metallic cobalt crystallites from ex situ measurements. Mean sizes of metallic cobalt crystallites were determined from hydrogen chemisorption data and they are larger than those of cobalt oxide in fresh catalysts (61–72nm for PR-series and 92–165nm for CA-series). The presence of potassium promoter increased the mean size of metallic cobalt crystallites, at a higher extend in the case of CA catalysts series. The calcined samples were analysed by the X-ray diffraction (Fig. 1 ). The XRD patterns of all samples are very similar. The patterns show typical reflections of a wurtzite-type phase (ZnO ICDD 01-78-3325, Zn0.9Co0.1O ICDD 01-78-3332, Zn0.8Co0.2O ICDD 01-78-3335) and a spinel-type phase (Co3O4 ICDD 00-42-1467 and ZnCo2O4 ICDD 00-23-1390). Analysing diffraction patterns it can be seen that zinc oxide is the main phase. It is important to note, that it is quite difficult to distinguish between the diffraction lines of ZnO and Zn1-x Co x O or Co3O4 and Zn x Co3-x O4. Pairs of these compounds have the same wurtzite (P63mc) and spinel cubic structure (Fd3m), respectively, differing only slightly in the size of the lattice. Taking into account catalysts composition and preparation, the possibility of simultaneously occurrences of ZnO, Co3O4 and double oxides phases is possible. Despite the fact that CoAl2O4, Co2AlO4 or ZnAl2O4 binary oxides are thermodynamically allowed, the low calcination temperature (T =400°C) makes it rather difficult to create those compounds as separate phases. The similarity of XRD patterns indicates that the addition of potassium in the studied range and the preparation method do not affect the crystalline phases of the catalysts. The Raman spectra obtained with a low laser power (Table 2 , Fig. 2 ) give more information on the surface composition of the catalysts. Spectra of catalysts obtained with precipitation method are very similar, while some differences can be noticed in the CA catalysts series. The 0K–CA sample spectrum differs quite significantly from the rest of that series. Considering that cobalt oxide spinel structures belong to the Fd3m space group five Raman active modes (A 1g +E g + 3F 2g) are expected: A1g (693cm−1), F 2g (622, 524 and 199cm−1) and E g (484cm−1) [18] (Table 2). In the case of ZnO the group theory predicts the following Raman active modes A 1 +E 1 + 2E 2 [34] which are represented by 204, 337, 410, 442, 539, 585, 659 and 806cm−1 peaks in ZnO–Al2O3 catalysts support [18]. The presence of the cobalt oxide spinel structure in our samples is represented by Raman active modes at 192, 487, 523, 618, 686cm−1 for the PR-series and 192, 486, 524, 622, 690cm−1 for the CA-series (Table 2, Fig. 2). No bands corresponding to ZnO–Al2O3 support are present in the samples spectra. According to Bhargava et al. [35] even small addition of Co3O4 to ZnO containing materials destroys ZnO lattice what is in agreement with the obtained spectra. In addition, CoAl2O4, ZnAl2O4 binary oxides can be excluded according to the lack of week bands at about 408–417 and 750–767cm−1 common characteristic of aluminium-based spinel [35] (Table 2). On all spectra the additional peaks at 154 and 209cm−1 can be seen and broadening of the strongest mode (686–690cm−1) is noticeable, when compared to pure Co3O4 spectrum [18]. Two peaks around strong cobalt oxide mode, F 2g, (192cm−1) can be assigned to species substances consisted simultaneously of four elements: oxygen, cobalt, zinc and aluminium [12,18,36]. Fitting of the band at 640–740cm−1 with Gaussian–Lorentzian amplitude algorithm gives the evidence of three peaks: main, corresponding to A 1g mode 686, 690cm−1; plus 667, 670cm−1; and 708, 709cm−1, respectively for PR and CA catalysts series (Table 2). It is probable that a greater part of this effect is related to insertion of Zn2+ into the lattice of spinel. In the spinel oxides, the spectral region around 600–700cm−1 is characteristic of vibrations involving the motion of oxygen atoms inside the octahedral unit (CoO6 in Co3O4). Its broadness is related to the cation–anion bond lengths and polyhedral distortion occurring in spinel lattice [35]. The formation of ZnCo2O4 was shown by Rubio-Marcos et al. [34], where Raman peak at ∼714cm−1 was attributed to the zinc-cobalt double oxide formation. Moving on from this, peaks at 708, 709cm−1 and at 667, 670cm−1 can be classified as connected with zinc-cobalt binary oxide formation. A very week band appears in the 590–600cm−1 region. Boix et al. [37] assigned it to high dispersed Co x O y species on Al2O3 surface. As alumina coincide with zinc oxide, some cobalt may exist in a high dispersed, amorphous state on the surface of ZnO and/or Al2O3. That Co x O y species correspond with reduction peaks hereinafter presented above 545 and 600°C. It suggests, that usage of both preparation methods lead to good mixing of the phases. This results in a good dispersion of cobalt oxide phase and facilitates the double oxide (CoZn2O4) formation. The Raman results, diffraction patterns and TPR profiles of those catalysts complement each other. It can be deduced that in examined catalysts ZnO, Co3O4, Zn1-x Co x O and Zn x Co3-x O4 phases coexist. The temperature-programmed reduction profiles show some differences in reducibility between PR- and CA-series (Fig. 3 ). All of them exhibit at least three hydrogen consumption peaks which separation is marked stronger for the CA catalysts series. The first two of them (clearly seen unresolved for PR catalysts) may correspond to the well known two-step reduction of cobalt oxide to metallic cobalt (Co3O4 →CoO→Co) [16]. The next range (above 620°C – PR-series, and 545°C – CA-series) resulted from reduction of cobalt oxides much more strongly interacting with the support with formation of the above mentioned binary cobalt-zinc oxides as well as with the reduction of some part of ZnO, facilitated by the presence of metallic cobalt [18]. Addition of potassium for PR-series catalysts clearly shifted the onset of reduction to lower temperature (from 200 to 150°C), what is in agreement with Casanovas et al. study [16]. In contrary, TPR profiles of CA-catalysts extend to higher temperatures and potassium addition did not lead to lowering of the reduction temperature of cobalt oxides. Potassium incorporation into the bulk of catalysts during preparation (where all catalysts components were simultaneously present in solutions used) could be the reason for such behaviour. It should be noted that alumina addition to the catalyst (∼4wt.%) did not impact the TPR results. According to the data collected by Wang et al. [12] only as high content of aluminium oxide as 10wt.% and more affect reducibility of Co/ZnO–Al2O3 catalysts. When compared the TPR results with the size of crystallites and the surface area of cobalt active phase it is seen that the easier reduction of PR catalysts led to smaller cobalt crystallites and higher active surface area than those in CA-series catalysts. 3.2 Ethanol steam reforming The long-term performance of both two series of catalysts in the SRE were evaluated at 420°C. The catalytic behaviour of the catalysts in the ethanol steam reforming conditions (H2O:EtOH=21:1 molar ratio) is presented in Fig. 4 in terms of ethanol and water conversions and hydrogen and carbon dioxide yield versus reaction time. The significant effect of potassium addition can be seen. In terms of stability of catalytic properties, 0K–PR and 0K–CA catalysts deactivated with time under reaction conditions; the ethanol conversion started to decrease after few hours (from 100% to 77% for the 0K–CA and to 93% for the 0K–PR catalyst). Unmodified catalysts are showing also continuous decrease of hydrogen and carbon dioxide yield. This phenomenon can be observed to a greater extent in the case of the 0K–CA catalyst. In the case of the 0K–CA catalyst, and in a smaller extend for the 0K–PR catalyst, the lowering conversion of ethanol is accompanied with its non-selective transformation — the quit large amounts of acetaldehyde (9% over the 0K–PR, 22% over the 0K–CA after 24h of the time-on-stream), small amounts of acetone (∼1% after 24h), also carbon monoxide (6–7% after 24h) and methane were formed in side reactions (Fig. 5 ). An reflection of side reactions can be find in the process selectivity to hydrogen and carbon dioxide. Both of them are decreasing, for the 0K–PR catalyst from 93% to 91% for H2 and from 86% to 75% for CO2. In the case of the 0K–CA catalyst — from 90% to 87% for H2 and from 73% to 63% for CO2. The potassium promoter allowed to stabilize the steam reforming. Potassium doped catalysts enable complete conversion of ethanol and a high conversion of water (Fig. 4). Moreover, hydrogen yield achieved the value of 5.5–5.3mol H2/mol EtOH, while CO2 yield stayed on the level of 1.8–1.7molCO2/mol EtOH during the experiment (H2O:EtOH=21:1 molar ratio), along with the high stability of the selectivity to the most desirable products - hydrogen and carbon dioxide were in the range of 95–98% and 89–95%, respectively (Fig. 5). Also, the selectivity towards carbon monoxide dropped to 2.7–3.3% and it was constant during 24h of the reaction. Some amounts of methane were also noticeable (Fig. 5). The increasing of potassium loading resulted in a drop of CH4 formation. Due to the presence of the promoter, production of undesirable acetaldehyde and acetone was completely depressed with the exceptions of the catalysts promoted with 2wt.% of potassium. For the 2K-PR and the 2K-CA trace amounts of CH3CHO in last hours on stream under reaction conditions were detected (∼1%). The products formed over promoted catalysts were mainly hydrogen, carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide and methane. Among the tested catalysts, the 1K-PR and the 2K-PR displayed the highest stability in terms of hydrogen and carbon dioxide yields and selectivities. Drawing on the above statement all catalysts from the PR-series were evaluated under the SRE with the H2O:EtOH=15:1 and 12:1 molar ratio (Fig. 6 and Fig. 7). As previously under the H2O:EtOH=21:1 molar ratio the unmodified catalyst activity and selectivity were unsatisfactory. The ethanol conversion as well as hydrogen and carbon dioxide yields dropped quite significantly (Fig. 6). Deactivation process led to non-selective transformations and the quite large amounts of acetaldehyde (33–24%), small amountss of acetone (<3) and trace amount of ethylene (<0.4%) were formed in side reactions (Fig. 7 ) Potassium addition improved catalysts performance. Nevertheless, incorporation of 1wt.% of potassium was not sufficient to inhibit catalyst deactivation under the smallest concentration of water among reactants vapours (H2O:EtOH=12:1 molar ratio). The ethanol conversion was maintained at the level of 100% for 5–12h on the stream (Fig. 6). After this time a slight decrease can be seen, to 94% for the H2O:EtOH=15:1 (1K-PR and 2K-PR) and to 88% for the H2O:EtOH=12:1 vapours stream (2K-PR). Simultaneously with the activity, also hydrogen and carbon dioxide yields tend to a slight drop after 8h of the test. For the H2O:EtOH=15:1 reactants vapours, the hydrogen yield goes down from 5.5/5.1 to 4.5/4.9molH2/mol EtOH (for the 2K-PR/1K-PR, respectively), while the CO2 yield drops from 1.8 to 1.6mol CO2/mol EtOH in the case of both promoted catalysts. Lowering of the water excess resulted in a stronger decrease of both those values in the presence of the promoted catalysts. When discussing the selectivity of the SRE process under the smaller water excess than H2O:EtOH=21:1 it is worth to notice that catalysts modified with potassium show very similar products distribution in both reactants mixtures (H2O:EtOH=15:1 and 12:1) (Fig. 7). In general, H2 and CO2 selectivity are very gently decreasing from 97–94 to 93–91 and from 91–87 to 85–81, respectively. The selectivity to methane reaches the value of 7–8% after 24h while the selectivity toward carbon monoxide stabilizes at the level of 4–4.5% and the selectivity of acetaldehyde formation increases to 4–7% after 24h of the SRE. Summing up the behaviour of both series of catalysts in the steam reforming of ethanol it is clear that among unpromoted catalysts noticeable better performance of the 0K–PR than that of the 0K–CA catalyst is seen. Especially, when its physico-chemical properties (the greater specific surface and cobalt surface area, as well as smaller crystallites of Co0, Co3O4 and slightly greater cobalt content) are compared with physico-chemical properties of the 0K–CA catalyst (Table 1). The results of the steam reforming of ethanol carried out over cobalt catalysts promoted with potassium stand in a line with earlier scientific reports [11,15–17,21–25]. In general, potassium addition improved catalysts performance in the SRE. When both series performance is compared undergo the H2O:EtOH=21:1 only it is not easy to declare what method of potassium incorporation was more efficient (Figs. 4 and 5). Though there are differences in performance under SRE for 0K–PR and 0K–CA catalysts and in their physico-chemical properties potassium incorporation resulted in equating of their catalytic properties. Although, 1K-CA and 2K-CA catalysts presented slightly better activity and selectivity in the first few hours on stream, the most stable performance was presented by 1K-PR and 2K-PR catalysts in the terms of ethanol and water conversions, hydrogen and carbon dioxide yields and the selectivity. The evaluation of PR-series catalysts led to the conclusion that lowering of water excess in vapours stream is followed by incomplete ethanol conversion and organic oxygen-containing by-products formation. Increasing of potassium content (from 1 to 2wt.%) did not give significant effects unless the smallest excess of water in reactants vapours (H2O:EtOH=12:1) was used. The potassium promoted co-precipitated catalyst (2K-PR) under such conditions allowed to achieve higher conversions of ethanol and water what was reflected in the higher process efficiency to hydrogen and carbon dioxide when compared to the performance of the 1K-PR catalyst. Concluding, catalysts from PR-series are more efficient in the SRE, potassium promoter improved the activity, selectivity and stability of catalysts performance. Nevertheless, only high molar ratio of the H2O:EtOH=21:1 and potassium addition can ensure total conversion of ethanol in a long-term SRE process. 3.3 Coking of catalysts in the ethanol steam reforming For the PR and CA catalysts series coking measurements in the water-ethanol vapours stream (with the 21:1 molar ratio) as well as in vapours streams with the H2O:EtOH=15:1 and 12:1 for PR-series were performed. The catalysts weight changes during ethanol conversion at 420°C were obtained from TG measurements (Fig. 8 ). It can be observed that TG profiles are results of two phenomena: the reduction of catalysts and carbon deposition. The weight of the 0K–CA sample increased only in the beginning of the SRE process and then it was decreasing while TG profiles obtained for 1K-CA and 2K-CA catalysts showed an initial small increase and then the weight stabilization (<2%) are observed. The formation of coke deposits after the end of the SRE was also confirmed by the Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 9 ). In the Raman spectra of CA-series catalysts, cobalt oxide bands are merely marked. The surface of all CA-series catalysts were covered by coke (1310cm−1 and 1600cm−1 bands, disordered carbonaceous and ordered graphitic species, respectively [15]). It can be noticed that potassium (added in one step together with other salts during CA catalysts preparation) did not hold off coke formation but allowed to preserve only a small amount of coke deposit formation on catalysts surface when the large excess of water during the SRE process is used. It could be a consequence of potassium incorporation into the bulk of cobalt catalysts during its preparation. For the catalysts from the PR-series a significant coke deposition takes place only for the smallest excess of water in reactant vapours (Fig. 8). The rate and amount of carbon deposited on the 1K-PR under vapours stream of H2O:EtOH=12:1 molar ratio were significantly higher than in the case of any other catalyst. What is more, the conversion of ethanol on this catalyst was decreasing with the highest rate (among promoted catalysts) (Fig. 6). Quite large amount of carbonaceous deposit was formed also in the case of the 2K-PR catalyst used in the same reaction conditions. When considering coking phenomena in the H2O:EtOH=15:1 reaction mixture the increase of the weight of the 1K-PR catalyst is also discernible in the last few hours of the SRE. Catalysts weight measurements under the high excess of water in reactants stream (H2O:EtOH=21:1) did not showed any evidential coke deposit formation. However, Raman spectra (Fig. 9) taken for all PR-catalysts after 24h of the steam reforming at 420°C (H2O:EtOH=21:1 molar ratio) showed two bands around 1310cm−1 and 1600cm−1. The spectra bands corresponding to cobalt oxide are clearly visible only for potassium promoted catalysts. Simultaneously, there was complete ethanol conversion on those catalysts and product distribution exhibited mainly the formation of H2, CO2, CH4 and CO. It can be deduced that PR-series promoted catalysts covered with only small amounts of the coke deposit and therefore it did not affect catalysts performance in the SRE under the high excess of water in the reactant stream. Higher amounts of potassium results in a greater ability to limit carbonaceous deposit formation, what is followed by more efficient performance of catalysts. Above results correspond with earlier research in which authors showed that only homogeneous distribution of coke deposits on unmodified catalysts surface affect the catalyst performance under SRE [12]. Llorca et al. [15], Rio et al. [23] and Ogo et al. [25] accomplished with the statement that alkali addition inhibits phenomena of abundant carbonaceous deposition and prevents cobalt active phase from over-reduction to metallic cobalt under SRE. All those aspects of potassium incorporation into the catalyst results in decrease of carbon species formation and in increase of catalysts performance in the SRE. Ogo et al. [25] clarified that the adsorption of intermediate acetate onto metallic cobalt is stabilized by potassium addition, what brought high stability and activity of cobalt catalyst for SRE (in the terms of complete ethanol conversion, high hydrogen yield and suppression of methane formation and carbon deposition). We may conclude that the coke formation with an encapsulation of catalyst active phase particles are justified reason of deactivation of catalysts. Taking into account the extend of catalysts coking, together with their activity and selectivity in the steam reforming of ethanol as well as their phisico-chemical properties, the 2K-PR catalyst is the most efficient one under various SRE conditions. 4 Conclusions The stability of activity and selectivity is an important characteristic of any catalyst since it determines its efficient use in a reaction. Usage of co-precipitation method along with potassium incorporation in the second step by incipient wetness impregnation resulted in the K–Co–ZnO–Al2O3 catalyst (∼28wt.% Co+2wt.% K) of the high effectiveness and stability for hydrogen production at the low-temperature steam reforming of ethanol. The presence of potassium inhibits carbonaceous deposition formation, enhances catalytic performance in terms of H2 and CO2 yields and stability of the SRE process selectivity when compared with unpromoted catalyst. The efficiency of the potassium promotion is higher when it is deposited on the catalyst surface with smaller cobalt active phase crystallites (prepared by the co-precipitation). Such catalysts are easier reducible than those obtained by the citrate method. Under SRE conditions the cobalt active phase in potassium promoted co-precipitated catalysts is partially oxidized, cobalt oxide seems to have a profitable effect on their resistance to coking and stability of the SRE effects. However, even potassium-promoted co-precipitated K–Co–ZnO–Al2O3 catalyst needs the water–ethanol feed with a large water excess, corresponding to the H2O:EtOH molar ratio higher than 15:1 for its stable behaviour. coredata.dc:description: The promotion effect of potassium on Co–ZnO–Al2O3 catalysts in the steam reforming of ethanol has been studied with samples prepared by co-precipitation and citrate methods. Experimental results of catalytic activity, selectivity and coke deposition phenomena are reported. Potassium addition (1 and 2wt.%) had a significant influence on catalytic efficiency at various ethanol+water vapours streams (H2O:EtOH=21:1, 15:1, 12:1 molar ratios). It acts as a promoter improving catalyst stability, activity as well as marginalizing coke deposition on the catalyst surface. Catalysts prepared by the co-precipitation method, with smaller cobalt active phase crystallites and with potassium deposited on the catalyst surface are more stable in the steam reforming of ethanol than those with large crystallites prepared by citrate method, into which potassium was introduced together with all others components. The efficiency of the potassium promotion is higher when it is deposited on the catalyst surface with smaller cobalt active phase crystallites. The water excess equivalent to the H2O:EtOH molar ratio higher than 15:1 has been necessary for the stable SRE. Even potassium-promoted K–Co–ZnO–Al2O3 catalyst needs the ethanol–water feed with a large excess of water.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of potassium addition on a long term performance of Co–ZnO–Al2O3 catalysts in the low-temperature steam reforming of ethanol: Co-precipitation vs citrate method of catalysts synthesis
